laboratory_examinations.findings: PSA level was 7.6 ng/mL (reference range: 0 to 4 ng/mL) at initial diagnosis, 0.6 ng/mL twenty-two months after brachytherapy, and <0.1 ng/mL five years after the procedure.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: PSA levels decreased from 7.6 ng/mL to <0.1 ng/mL over ten years.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Revealed microscopic hematuria. PSA level was reportedly <0.2 ng/mL.
Reportedly showed malignant cells suggestive of adenocarcinoma.
Revealed a benign-appearing bladder with some irregularities of the prostatic urethra.
Showed abnormal signal in the prostate and right seminal vesicle, consistent with postradiation changes; prostate cancer could not be ruled out.
Examination of the bladder was normal, prostatic urethra was narrow and rigid; tissue revealed invasive adenocarcinoma.
